body:
Okay then, I see this has brought out the pitchforks. I would kindly ask those of you who have them to put them away and let's have a fun, no harm, technical discussion. We are the Ruby community afterall, not the PHP one.

DHH and I have talked tonight on the Rails Campfire. I really appreciate the time he's spending on Rails even though he has a business to run.

We have decided that this feature should be opt-out in much the same way that ActiveRecord currently is. 

For those of you who are unfamiliar with this, the current way of doing this when you generate a new application to pass the `--skip-active-record` option which changes the top of `config/application.rb` from requiring `rails/all` to requiring all the railties in [`rails/all`](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/master/railties/lib/rails/all.rb) with the exception of the `active_record/railtie` file. This leaves you open to use the other ORMs that you know and love.

Now, with this Sprockets change, we've discussed that it would be best to have the `sprockets-rails` gem as a dependency of the `actionpack` gem, but to have `sprockets-rails` activated when `config.assets.enabled` is set to `true`. I realise that as `sprockets-rails` would be a dependency of `actionpack` that this means that `sprockets-rails` would still be required (just like any other gem in your Gemfile or a dependency of those gems, and so on). But by using this flag we will enable the functionality provided by this gem.

So there you have it, a nice way forward that allows you to use both Sprockets and whatever you like, with Sprockets still being the "on-by-default" default.
